titleStmt.title: Basic Research for Coloring Multichannel MRI Data

analytic.title: Basic Research for Coloring Multichannel MRI Data

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: This is basic research for assigning color values to voxels of multichannel MRI volume data. The MRI volume datasets obtained under different scanning conditions are transformed to the components by independent component analysis (ICA), which enhances physical characteristics of the tissue. The transfer functions for generating color values from independent components are obtained using the radial basis function network, a kind of neural net, by training the network with sample data chosen from visible female data set. The resultant color volume datasets correspond well with the full-color cross-sections of the visible human datasets.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Recently, techniques such as virtual endoscopes [1] or surgical simulations [2] have become popular new tools for diagnosis or education in the field of medicine. These techniques use 3D anatomical models of each patient for graphical display, but the models are usually derived from 3D images obtained by diagnostic devices such as CT or MRI. Although these images show the anatomical structure of the patient with an accuracy of millimeters, the contrasts represent the attenuation coefficient of the X-ray beam for CT or the time constant of spin relaxation for MRI, which are not the color representations. Therefore, the tissue colors used in the virtual endoscopes or the surgical simulations are empirically determined without using these contrasts [3]. We believe that the contrast information is very useful to color the model and such kind of color will be powerful assistance for 3D diagnosis, surgical planning and real time navigation for the surgery or other treatments. This is basic research for obtaining color volume data by using MRI. The problem of translating MRI contrasts to color values is somewhat like the problem of generating a transfer function for volume rendering [4,5]. We think that the past research on transfer function generation was hindered because it used single channel volume data. We therefore use multichannel MRI data obtained under different scanning conditions to generate color volume data. T1-weighted, T2-weighted and proton-density-weighted MRI are popular scanning modalities in practical medical diagnosis [6] and are promising candidates for the multichannel MRI of our research. Since the contrasts in these images are not direct representations of the relaxation time or the proton density but are "weighted" contrasts, they may vary with the differences in devices or absolute values of the scanning parameters. Furthermore, those images are highly correlated with each other and are regarded as a mixture of physically independent components. We therefore use independent component analysis (ICA) [7] to transform these MRI data into different representations (e.g., fat and free water), which enhance the physical characteristics of tissues [8].

The relation between independent components (ICs) and the tissue color is represented by three transfer functions. In the field of medicine, there are some attempts of simultaneously displaying multiple MRI data by using color [9][10][11][12]. However, those methods cannot generate tissue color, since they were just making linear mapping between the MRI parameter and the color coordinate axis. Then we use radial basis function (RBF) network [13] to generate the non-linear mapping functions from training sample data chosen from the Visible Female Dataset (VFD) distributed by the Visible Human Project (VHP) of the National Library of Medicine (NLM) [14]. Using the resultant transfer functions, we hope to assign color values for any multichannel MRI data and to consequently develop color MRI.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 explains the multimodality image registration method, and section 3, the concept of ICA. In section 4, we introduce the RBF network for generating the transfer functions. In section 5, we generate color volume datasets from a few examples of multichannel MRI datasets by using the resultant transfer functions. Problems and future work will be discussed in section 6.

div.head: Sample Dataset 2.1 Visible Female Dataset
div.p: To learn the relations between the multichannel MRI and the tissue color, we need sample data. The most suitable data is available from the visible female data set (VFD), which is distributed by the Visible Human Project (VHP) of the National Library of Medicine (NLM) [14].

The VFD is a collection of transverse digitized slice images of the whole body of a female cadaver, which consists of full-color photo images, CT images and three MRI datasets (T1-weighted, T2-weighted and proton-density-weighted MRI). In this research, we use the full-color images and the three MRI datasets of the head area. In the field of image processing, there are a considerable number of research papers on registering two datasets [15]. Most of them extract certain geometrical features such as edges or landmarks from both datasets and find the transformation for one data set, which minimizes the discrepancies with the features of the other data set. However, if the types of data set differ, the features may also differ and making it difficult to evaluate the discrepancies. We therefore use a registration method based on the maximization of mutual information (MMI) [16], which is suitable for the multimodality data registration.

div.head: Multimodality Data Registration
div.p: We explain the MMI registration method by using an example of fitting the red channel of the full-color images of VFD to the T1-weighted MRI data set of VFD. We represent the T1weighted MRI data set as reference data (r), and the transformed red channel images by a transformation α as floating data (f ).

For simplicity, we assume that the red channel images have already been transformed to the same scale as r and that α is a rigid body transformation having six unknowns (three translations and three rotations). Figure 1 (e) has less dispersion than Figure 1 (d), meaning that a certain intensity of r corresponds to a certain intensity of f . We can find this kind of transformation α by minimizing the mutual information value

div.head: Independent Component Analysis
div.p: The purpose of this paper is to assign a color for a voxel of an Mdimensional multichannel MRI data set. This problem is considered to be the mapping from an M-dimensional data space to a three-dimensional color space. In VFD, three modalities of MRI datasets are available, i.e. T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and proton-density-weighted MRI. These modalities are distinguished just by the relative values of repetition time (TR) and echo time (TE) of the spin echo pulse sequence [6]. Although they are used in daily diagnosis, the contrasts in these modalities are not direct representations of the relaxation times or the proton density but are "weighted" contrasts. Therefore, these contrasts are not linearly independent and may change depending on the absolute values of TR and TE or on the differences of the scanning device itself.

Let us assume that the datasets are represented as x m ( m = 1 3 ,2, ) as shown in Figure 3. We assume that the M- Principal component analysis (PCA) is widely used to decorrelate datasets but cannot identify independent sources. We therefore use independent component analysis (ICA) [7]. ICA separates independent source signals from the mixed observed signals. Recently, ICA has been used for many fields such as mixed voice separation [18] or functional MRI analysis [19]. There are several ways to make each y i independent,
including the minimization of mutual information approaches [20,21] and the nonlinear PCA [22]. In any case, we can use the Natural Gradient,
to modify W as W W W = + ∇ η .
where η is a learning coefficient. However, we use a more sophisticated modification method in this paper. (See Appendix 1)
Mathematically, nonlinear functions
are cumulative density functions of y i . However, there is no way to define the probability density function of unknown sources.

Usually, we use the sigmoid function [20] or approximate ϕ i i ( ) y by using the high-order statistic values of y k [21], where E{ }means the expectation value. The latter method can separate both sub-Gaussian and super-Gaussian sources, while the former method only separates super-Gaussian sources [21]. However, from our experience, the former method is more stable, and sub-Gaussian sources are rarely observed in MRI data. We thus use the former method in this paper. If datasets are independent, there is no correlation between them. By using this feature, we can simplify ICA by using a procedure called whitening. (See Appendix 1.) Figure 4 shows the results of applying ICA to X as:

div.head: S s s s WX
div.p: In Figure 4 (b), fat tissue in bone marrow and eye surroundings have higher intensity, and the white matter, which is rich in myelin, is well recognized. We assume s 2 to be fat in the image. s 3 is considered to represent free water since the intensity in eyeballs and cerebrospinal fluid is high in Figure 4 (c). s 1 seems to be a residual image of s 2 and s 3 . This residual seems to represent water that has a relatively short relaxation time [8].

Consequently, we can separate physically independent components from the multichannel MRI data by using ICA. These components are suitable for determining the correspondence with the tissue color since the values are considered to be stable with respect to differences in the scanning parameters or devices.

div.p: In this section, we discuss the problem of mapping from an M-

div.head: Clustering
div.p: In this paper, we use clustering techniques for several purposes, e.g., arranging the basis function, selecting the training samples, and calibrating independent components. We do not mention the details of the clustering algorithms here. However, the k-mean method [23] is a well-established clustering technique.

div.head: Selecting Training Samples
div.p: As shown in Figure 2, even if the datasets are registered, the MRI datasets and the full-color data do not match completely in some areas, e. g. around the back of the head. Then we use a non-linear 2D registration technique [23] for the full-color data. The training samples were regularly selected from the corresponding pixels of the independent components (s 1 ,s 2 ,s 3 ) and the deformed full-color data.

div.head: Coloring Visible Female MRI
div.p: All experiments were performed on an SGI ONYX2 (R10000 195MHz) single CPU. As shown in Figure 2, the T2-weighted ( x 2 ), proton-density-weighted MRI ( x 3 ), and the full-color images (c c c
, , ) of VFD were fitted to the T1-weighted MRI data set ( x 1 ) of VFD by using the MMI registration method. The computation time was from one to two hours for each data set.
We applied ICA to the registered MRI datasets X ICA has the weak point of uncertainty of the scale and the permutation, so we defined the rules as:
• s 1 has higher intensity in the area of the gray matter of brain than in the background. • s 2 has the highest intensity in fat area (e.g. bone marrow).
• s 3 has the highest intensity in free water area (e.g. eyeballs).
All ICs are normalized so that the maximum value is 1 and the minimum value is 0.
We used the k-mean method to classify each IC into six classes (K1=K2=K3=6, P=216). The cluster centers g m k

, were used to arrange the RBF, where λ = 1 for Eq. 6. We then used the method of 4.4 to choose training sample data (N=63018). The RBF network was used to learn the transfer functions from the training sample data. We used the pinv function of MATLAB to solve the pseudo-inverse Φ * of Eq. 5. The computation time for generating transfer functions was about 5 minutes. by applying the resultant transfer functions. Although the bone marrow areas have some speckles, they are in good agreement with the same slices of the full-color images as shown in Figures 7(d), (e) and (f).

div.head: Coloring Visible Male MRI
div.p: In this subsection, we will try to generate color volume data from the multichannel MRI data set of the visible male data set (VMD). The VMD is almost the same as the VFD except that the cadaver is a male and the interval of the full-color images is 1 mm. Figures 8 (a)

where g m a , is the a-th cluster center of the m-th IC of VFD. These parameters are chosen to match areas containing the same tissue. For example, g 2 6 , is the cluster center of VFD whose cluster contains fat area, and ′ g 2 6 Figures 10 (a), (b) and (c) show three slices of the color volume data generated from ICs of VMD by applying the transfer functions of VFD. The white matter, the gray matter and the background colors are in good agreement with the colors of Figures 7 (d), (e) and (f). Figures 10 (d), (e) and (f) show the full-color images of VMD, which look brighter than those of Figures 10 (a), (b) and (c). We think this is due to differing lighting conditions between VMD and VFD.

div.head: Coloring Normal Volunteer's MRI
div.p: So far, we have colored multichannel MRI datasets of cadavers. In this subsection, we will try to generate color volume data from a multichannel MRI data set of a normal volunteer.
We obtained three MRI datasets, i.e., T1-weighted, T2weighted and proton-density-weighted MRI, of a normal volunteer by using a spin echo sequence on a 1.5 T MRI scanner.
The parameters were matrix 256 256 × , 5mm thick, 25 slices.

The combination of TR and TE for each data set is shown in Table 1. As in the results of cadavers, three components, i.e. water with a relatively short spin relaxation time, fat and free water, were also separated for the normal volunteer. We used the calibration functions shown in Figure 12. Figure 13 is the result of the generation of color volume data.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In Figures 13 (a), (b) and (c), granular noise can be seen all over the images. However, most of the noise is found in the first IC as shown in Figure 11 (g). We reduced the number of classes of the first IC to K1=2 as Figure 14 and generated the transfer functions again. Figure 15 displays the results of the color volume generation using 72 RBFs in total (K1=2, K2=K3=6). The quality of images is better than in Figure 13. This kind of noise reduction is considered to be a strong point of ICA.

The improved results when we reduce the number of classes of the first IC may be due to several causes. One possibility is that the first IC is not a pure component. If we have one more channel, i.e. another scanning modality of MRI, the first IC may be Figure 13 were obtained from a normal volunteer while the transfer functions were generated from the datasets of a cadaver. Since the chemical characteristics of the living body and the cadaver must differ, it is quite natural that Figure 13 does not match Figure 7 or Figure 10. In this case, the first IC, which we call "water with a relatively short spin relaxation time," is considered to differ more than the second and the third components between a living body and a dead body.

In Figure 15, the areas of bone marrow are darker than those of Figures 7 (d), (e) and (f). This is also considered to be due to the differences between a living body and a dead body. The cadaver was perfused with formalin, which may change the spin relaxation time in some areas. The training sample of Figure 7 (b) does not contain much of those areas. This might be another reason.

div.head: Conclusions and Future Work
div.p: In this paper, we presented the results of our basic research on coloring multichannel MRI data. By using the RBF network, we could obtain the transfer functions to generate color component values from the independent components of multichannel MRI datasets. The visible female data set was used to generate the training sample data for the network. The resultant color volume datasets are in good agreement with the full-color images of the visible female data for both examples (cadavers and a normal volunteer). This technique will be useful for generating color anatomical models for virtual endoscopies and surgical simulations.

Currently, our method needs manual calibration to fit the ICs to those of VFD. This process can be performed automatically and more accurately if we acquire multichannel MRI datasets with a certain reagent. Some problems seem to arise from the differences of relaxation time between a dead body and a living body. We are planning to investigate the relations between multichannel MRI datasets and the tissue color for a living body in our future work.

We believe this technique is also useful for enhancing pathology. However, the number of datasets we have analyzed is too small to say something. Now we are studying a method to handle the exceptional combination of independent components. We will present this result in our next paper after we have investigated sufficient number of clinical datasets. Figure 16 Experiments of eight channels data set.

The radial basis function (RBF) network [16] is suitable for generating functions like Eq. 4. The RBF approach defines a function by linear combinations of P basis functions as: M-dimensional vector and ω j p , is the weight coefficient. Although many kinds of basis functions are available, the Gaussian function is the most advantageous choice [13]. Once the shape and the arrangement of the basis function are decided, the weight coefficient ω j p , can be determined by using the training samples. To use ICA for multichannel MRI analysis, the datasets, Since the mean value of each x m is considered to be 0 in ICA, we assume that the mean value of every x m is subtracted in the preprocessing stage. We consider that X is observed as a combination of M independent source signals, iteratively so that each element of Y becomes as independent as possible. If the iteration converges, Y is considered to be equivalent to S apart from the scale and the permutation.

div.head: Appendix 1. Whitening
div.p: Whitening is a technique for simplifying ICA. It is also called sphering. If Σ x UDU =

T is the eigenvalue decomposition of the covariance matrix Σ x xx = E T { }, whitening is performed as follows: Nishimori proposed a method to update W along the geodesic flows in an orthogonal group and reported some advantages to Eq. 3 [25]. In this method, we use
instead of Eq. 3, where
This method is powerful for evaluating η , but it includes exp( ) ηX , which is an exponential of a skew symmetric matrix X and needs computationally expensive Schur decomposition [26] of X.

div.head: Appendix 2. How many channels are needed?
div.p: We investigated how many independent components are observed in the TR-TE combinations of spin echo MRI pulse sequences. Figure 16 ( suggesting that at most three components can be separated by changing TR and TE of the spin echo sequence. The first three components agree very well with the components we presented in this paper, i.e. water with a relatively short spin relaxation time, fat and free water, except the order of the second and the third components is reversed. Therefore, we believe that these components are stable with respect to differences of scanning parameters or the scanner itself, and are promising candidates for the information sources for color assignment.

We also confirmed that similar components could be separated only from three MRI datasets, e.g., Figures 16 (b), (d) and (f). However, in some combinations, e.g., Figures 16 (a), (b) and (c), we could not separate the three components. Therefore, more than four channels' MRI datasets should be used to obtain these three components. In such a case, we can use the whitening technique (see Appendix 1) to quickly obtain the three components by setting L=3.
We expect that we may be able to obtain more than four independent components by using pulse sequences other than the spin echo sequence.
